title: Swedish News — 15 February 2026
script:
Sweden's Migration Minister has announced a significant policy shift, saying teenagers should be allowed to complete their high school education — a move that affects young asylum seekers and migrants in the school system. The announcement comes as the Sweden Democrats leadership has reached internal agreement on residence permit policies, positioning the party to shape immigration regulations more formally.

In far-right monitoring news, attendance at the Salem march has hit a record low. The neo-Nazi march, a longstanding fixture in Swedish activism, drew fewer participants than ever before. Meanwhile, courts have been busy this week: three people have now been sentenced in the so-called Janouch scandal, another man has been sentenced for inciting drag queens, and a Nazi was convicted after disrupting a Social Democrat meeting. The Ombudsman's office has also written off a complaint against Sweden Democrats politician Richard Jomshof after an incitement investigation was abandoned — a decision that's now being challenged at the JO.

AI Sweden, the country's national AI initiative, has won recognition as societal actor of the year. The organisation has been expanding municipal adoption of AI tools and strengthening ties with Canada during high-level business visits. New training programmes are equipping civil society and the retail sector with AI capabilities, whilst labour market councils are preparing Swedes for how artificial intelligence will reshape employment.

On the international stage with Swedish implications, Ukraine and Russia are entering new peace talks next week. President Zelensky has proposed a two-month truce followed by elections, and is demanding at least 20 years of security guarantees from Western nations. A Swedish researcher has warned that Sweden's new frigates will become high-value military targets — an assessment that underscores the ongoing strategic importance of Nordic naval investment.

Finally, there's been renewed scrutiny of Sveriges Radio, Sweden's public broadcaster. A new debate has highlighted longstanding questions about the organisation's claim to political impartiality. The image of Sverige Radio as strictly apolitical has repeatedly been tested, with observers arguing that the principle of impartiality — how it's defined, applied, and maintained in practice — remains more myth than reality.
